title: 5 Things I Refuse to Spend Money On in 2026
subtitle: Discover the costly financial mistakes that savvy investors avoid for a more secure financial future.
content:
5 Things I Refuse to Spend Money On in 2026

Most financial advisors are gonna hate this. Here’s what I, Tyler, a former financial advisor and portfolio manager, will be avoiding this year.

1. Whole Life Insurance

This is marketed as an investment and insurance combination. But the reality is that it generates a 6% commission for your advisor and offers a meager 2% return for you. Not worth it.

2. Variable Annuities

Congratulations, your advisor gets a 6% to 7% commission to lock you into an annuity, complete with surrender charges and crippling fees. Leave this behind.

3. Front-Loaded Mutual Funds

You invest $10,000, and your advisor pockets $575 right off the bat as a commission. That means you start with just $9,425. It doesn’t make sense to give that much away.

4. Buffered ETFs

These funds tout having a downside protection floor, yet you end up paying 0.7% to 1% in fees just to hold them. The costs aren't justified by their benefits.

5. Paying an Advisor 1% of My Assets

No matter their performance, whether they beat the market or not, I refuse to pay an advisor 1% of my assets. Instead, I recommend checking out facet.com/tyler today. Their CFP professionals have your best interest at heart, offering financial planning without commissions or percentage-based fees.

Remember, it’s important to spend wisely. Avoid these five pitfalls for a more robust financial future.
